FM2016 is a great football management game, probably the best because there is no real competition. FIFA17's manager career mode is catching up, but it's nowhere near the sophistication of FM. 

A standout problem is the awful injuries that some players receive. A center attacking midfielder wonderkid that is fairly susceptible to injuries randomly picks up "damaged cruciate ligaments" in the Champions League final against Manchester City F.C. as his first big injury. Gone for 8-9 months. Don't joke with me. I can understand if he twists a knee or something because it's a month out injured. I quit and restart the game. Don't mess with me, Sports Interactive's game engine. That happened to me in FM2015 to my main striker, and I was dumb enough to save it. Ruined my striker's career. Imagine what would happen if my wonderkid lost a year of development. 

A more realistic change in scouting happened this year, you have no idea whether a youngster has world class potential or not. Back in FM2015, I can understand a 20-rated judging potential scout screws up on a "world class" assessment, but in FM2016, every scouting report and in-house coaching report says "Potential to become First Division player." Is this some sort of joke? I hire the best scouts (20-rated judging potential ability) with years of experience and that is the best assessment. Do you have no guts to say "Maybe, this youngster might be world class, boss?" What a disgrace. Most cases, I find out a player has "world class potential" after he's played around two seasons for my first-team squad. I don't care if you say that because by that time if the player's performed well, I already know where he stands in my squad. I don't need some two-year overdue paperwork when I can literally see the stats myself. 

You just have to decide a player's potential with those idiotic star ratings, which were poor in FM2015, but probably worse in FM2016. Four gold stars and one black star, he must be the player with the best potential on your team even world class I daresay, but no, he turns out to be some run of mill, average player on a good day. I often have much worse realities, such as two gold stars in the end. I rarely see a player with four-in-a-half gold stars and half black star rating, which I bet might be a better bet as a world class potential. I have stepped up my own judging ability, so I don't get screwed on expensive transfers of more-or-less probable wonderkids.

Also, think about not using the "world class" moniker so much. FInd a better term because the next tier is probably "Star of the First Division" or something like that, which could be improved. In scout reports, maybe "Champions League quality player" or "Europa League quality player" or "superstar quality player" might be slightly more accurate. 

I still recommend this game because it's still playable with its faults, and this is one of my favorite games. This is a visible improvement over FM2015 with more realistic transfers and better AI opponents. I have read those horrible reviews of FM2017, and I am a bit worried. The only other FM I played was FM2015, but FM2016 is definitely the best FM in my books.

Been playing since 09', and I've seen the FM franchise get better and better up to 15' which was a bit touch and go, and then 16' (This installment) which, I think, improved a lot from 15' but also went a few steps backwards from 15'.

Crazy results (Beating Barcelona 7-0 at the Nou Camp, then Real Madrid 8-2 at the Bernabeu...), retarded gameplay mechanics at times (Seriously you want that red card so bad? 2 minutes in, and all you wanna do is lunge in with the dumbest tackle ever?), the yellow and red card amounts are staggering and unbelievable, no matter what tactics I use my team regularly gets 3 yellow cards a game, sometimes twice on the same player... It makes for a frustrating experience at times.

The morale mechanics, contracts, transfers and overall tactics, as far as I can tell, have improved drastically. My tactics actually feel like they're making a difference (Aside for certain cases like stated above), and I love it. 

The game engine looks better and plays the same as 15', trading in new bugs for fixing older bugs - But overall this game makes for a very fun gaming experience.

If you have 15', don't buy 16'. If you don't have 15', buy 16'. Very simple. Not a game worth buying every single year, especially for a ludicrous 50$, but this installment is as good as any. Oh, and for the love of god, don't get 17'. It's dreadful.

I brought this game despite fully understanding its addictive nature (you could say this was a relapse). The last football management game I possessed was 2002 where a young me would spend hours watching and shouting at pixelated men in competition with local rivals for that last 6th position playoff spot in division 2 (Which wasn't achieved and the game was buried....).
Well for FM2016 (as the kids call it) you do feel more of a relation to the real modern game. If you support 'normal underachieving' everyday football team as myself (because you were raised up to/encouraged to support your roots and keep the hope..ect) on the right settings I'm happy to inform you can relive the same anguish, disappointed, ups and downs you get every Saturday as a fan at the same time seeing the perspective of your under the cosh running out of excuses manager. 
There you are, had a good strong start, made that important signing from a good proportion of your budget has a few great matches with your specialist yet slightly risky 4-3-3 formation, yet to find few games on he has a nasty 18 month injury. Anyway things start to just wobble so you make a few tweaks/consolations to help but things start going a bit more south and to worsen morale that player you thought you wouldn't use which you sold with no sell on fee is doing pretty well in a FA cup quarter final which you exited round 3 ("Just concentrating on the league" we tell ourselves). And all of a sudden with the chairman breathing down your neck you start thinking, "how did I have it setup before?? wish I saved it..." and "might move teams..."

All in all, like before I've played hours and hours now and like before I have no regrets and you shouldn't too. These games may not process the quality in graphics and gameplay as FIFA or PES (never expect that from FM) but the endless amount of strategy, options, care and attention you can add it can accommodate everybody's level of skill. Soooo relapse with me people! Relapse! Football give in to it!

This is my first installment of the game. Rumors has it that this is one of the worst installations of FM to come out thus far. I don't have that comparison to make so this is an unbiased review. The game is pretty fun but its very difficult to maintain a winning team. I was only able to do so for 1.5 seasons tops. After that the team turned to crap and there was no way to fix it. Id bring in many solid players, few solid players, change formation, listen to the assistant coaches advice and change focus but nothing ever worked. I usually just resigned and started over as soon as that happened. This is less likely to happen if you play with a strong team from the start (R.Madrid, Barcelona, Etc) but wheres the fun in that. I like working my way up the ranks. Promotion is oh so satisfying.

This game is worth buying, it is really fun and easy to play, and it is very immersive for all it's leagues. Mods are where the game gets a second life, as you can update from 2015-16 to 2016-17 and add club logos, kits, and even adding custom tournaments such as the now defunct UEFA Cup Winners' Cup and UEFA Intertoto Cup. 

I have over 1200+ hours on the game and it is worth all of those hours, and worth even more. The FM16 Editor really does help in you customising the game to your heart's desire, and it is a great addition to the game.

To conclude, Football Manager 2016 is worth buying if you enjoy Football.

I like most FMs. I have it since FM13. FM15 was easy in my opinion. FM 16 was completely hard. I struggled the whole game with different saves. Always conceded goals on counter attacks, no matter what high or low line I had and best or worst players. It's still a cool game. But I always played it and stopped because I got frustrated a lot. 

The reason I'm saying this is because I'm not one of this youtubers or streamers that play FM and only FM and figure out every single stuff in the game (aka the ME, Match Engine). I'm that guy passionate about football that like other games too. And to be honest this version of FM was the best in terms of up to date stuff about real football but imo the worst on gameplay experience (because of the struggles).

I still got about 650hs on it, my most played FM ever to date. This because I love challenges. But there are stuff that need changes and upgrades ASAP, like the training, the user friendly interface, like the tips for beginners or the help from the AI coaches because many of the stuff on FM has not that friendly user interface for beginners and that is something I always got annoyed by the series.

Other stuff is, if you understand REAL Football and study it, this doesn't mean you can be successful on FM. So that propaganda/marketing about real people using FM on clubs is just about the players attributes and stuff. Not the match engine for example. FM has a pretty good scout network that a lot of clubs use to get understanding of players they can't afford to scout.

Anyway, I as for today would not recommend this game for a newcomer. For a veteran yes. This game made me open my eyes to the series as for I'm not buying it on pre-order anymore and will not buy it every year, specially FM17. A lot of things have to change to make the game more realistic and more accessible and understandable. It's not like real football of FIFA/PES where you just watch a game and understand the logic behind the match engine. There is a lot more involved.

I will recommend the game because it is good. Has the up to date stuff from 2016 and FM17 doesn't have many changes compared to this one (from the announcements and watching people playing on streams) but the counter attacks are extremely aggressive imo. So be aware of the rage you are going to get with this game.

There are many ways to go about reviewing this game. The comparison between past entries in the series is one of the more popular yet I feel it does this game an injustice. My experience with FM 2016 has been very positive and it will take numerous edits to produce a review that includes all aspects of the game.

The main improvement is the feeling of true 'understanding' that builds as you play the game. At first inheriting a new squad is very daunting and can be tumultuous at the start of the season, you check scout reports identify weaknesses and yet these do not mean the be all and end all of a successful squad. Personality is now a key factor in squad cohesion and this is the first game in the series where they have really pulled it off. Not only this but the revamped tactics, which I didn't really like in 2015, actually make sense in accordance to the players now. It really does feel like you grow into the game and your squad grows with you.

The only way I can 'prove' this is through experience. I began a multiplayer save as Chesterfield sitting in League 1 of the football championship in England, the squad is ok, one player thought he was too big for the club and moved on to a higher league. I brought in loan signings who combined with my 4-2-3-1 strategy perfectly in a blend of speed and power that saw my team unexpectantly promoted in the play-offs. Next year I thought would be a big struggle, indeed it was yet I changed my formation to a solid 4-1-3-2 and brought in big midfielders and a new target man. I began to grind out results and realised this is the first time the football manager series has challenged me in such a way. My squad personality of 'determined' with many of the players having high work rate and teamwork mattered just as much as my refining the tactics and set pieces, whereas in past entries I would train a formation and never have to be reflexive in order to counter specific threats. Players stats used to determine so much and now that this has been toned down, buying and selling really takes far more nouse to be successful.

The graphics leave a little to be desired but perform their role. Sometimes the match engine makes it look like your players have lost all ability to play but if you look at the stats, how confident they are feeling and the specific feedback from your assistant you can be reflexive and resolve the issue before the match is lost. It really does feel like every decision has an impact on unlocking defences or solidifying your own. To this, the display does a very adept job.

I got promotion to the premier league with a squad of roughnecks and man mountains and got thouroughly deconstructed by almost every team. (barring Newcastle who I did the double over, lol) It was disheartening but also so very real, my solid wall wasn't paying off at the highest level so I reverted to buying smaller yet more skillful players, a few greek players to create a solid understanding between my foreign talent and the english core of the squad and two top class championship strikers. The 4-2-3-1 was back with a vengeance and we even had Sergio Romero the former Argentine international between the sticks, at Chesterfield!

The changes paid off over two seasons and many of the squad had each other and me, the manager as their 'favoured personel'. With this we regained our promotion and won our first trophy, the feeling was so much more sweet than past victories in any other footballing sim or any title. The story is there, different players react to each other in unique ways and this is the first game in the series where true understanding comes from more than just 'stats'. 


For these reasons I can safely say that this is the best entry in the series so far and I've played since 08. It might be worth waiting for the next rendition but this game would be a great purchase regardless.

1. Overpowered crossing - This is by far the biggest issue with this game. Near on 80% of ALL goals scored, for and against seem to originate from crosses. This is regarless of what your tactics are. I don't think much needs to be said other than play two or three seasons and have a look at Hector Bellerin's stats. I will happily bet my house, car and family that he has more assists than Ozil, and is consistently in the top 5 average rating for the league. Other attacking full backs; Gaya, Alba, Marcelo, Walker will have similar stats. This is a huge issue for the game creators and MUST be worked on for the next version.

2. Regens - This has been a long-running fixture in the SI wishlists. Though I acknowledge some slight progress has been made here, theres still plenty to be desired. There are too many youngsters that are too similar. The obvious example is with strikers. It is extremely rare, if not impossible, to find a striker who doesn't have great finishing (17), good first touch (14+), poor technique & composure (8) and is about 6' 2. Also, with wingers, now-a-days it's unusual to find an 'old school winger' who plays the the same side as his preffered foot. This is not reflective on the game and there are not nearly enough 'inside forwards' that come thhrough. I think SI need adapt witht the changing game, I wouldlike to see many more regens able to play on either wing with differing comfortability. Also, there needs to be some collaboration with attributes. E.G. you'd have a regen who is quick and good at dribbling, but then has something like 9 flair, poor agility and poor balance. Outside of maybe Jordan Ibe, I don't think this ever happens in real life. 

3. Player interactions - some of the reactions players have are just too unrealistic, and regardless of player personality, they all seem to react the same way. Football Manager, indeed, is a game for niche player base. The prerequisite is that you love football AND management, since if you don't you'll find it challenging to even start, no, I mean to buy the game. The gameplay is mostly the same (oh no, no pew pew purple beam here, so action game lover can't expect anything), without major changes in its core. At the very basic, this iteration is no different than previous Football Manager incarnations - the only major constant change is players/clubs data.

[u]User Interface[/u] 
User interface for this 2016 version is using direct link-Left Sidebar style. Some older versions used collapsible Sidebar (for nested 'Main Squad, U21, U18 for example), but none can be found in this 2016. Most major important elements are directly listed in the sidebar, but as it's limited in space due to it not being collapsible anymore, you'll be hard pressed to find some hidden or nested settings. One notable example is when trying to find "youth intake" list  requires me to move my cursor at least to *gasp* 4 different positions to expand dropdown/submenu, not to mention it's very hidden in obscure position. Definitely could use some UI improvement for the next iteration of FM.

If you're FM veteran this UI should be adaptable. But if you're new player, you'd need the help function in-game in order to even understand the menus.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
Almost no change than previous iterations. It's slowly expanded, but the basic premise of the game is for you to be a manager, control a club, train players and manage it. There are more updates introduced like more complex press conference, expanded contract negotiation screens and player interactions (man, I hate players complaining non stop about their contracts and their teammates' issues), but it's more like additional contents, the basic stays the same.

[u]Match engine[/u]
Frankly, the engine has evolved alot, be it UI and functionality. While the changes are ok as it makes things clearer to read (text-based info) than previous FMs, the main focus is the evolution of so called 3D match engine. I will not cover accusation from FM playerbase about AI cheating, as it cannot be proven with cold, hard truth without digging the codebase, but I can definitely say the 3D match engine is dumb. This isn't 2005, where this FM2016's match engine belongs. SI should stick with text based or even moving dot ala FM2009's. It is really aggravating looking at stiff players' gestures (imagine Playstation's Winning Eleven that's decade old already), incredibly weird ball physic / players pitch movement and all around display logic glitches.

I'd rather for 3D engine to be ditched to be quite honest. Better don't try anything than trying half assed thing like that.

[u]Replayability[/u]
Practically endless. You can try different leagues, teams, nations on a whim. You can even set up your own challenge by controlling minor/amateur club and getting that club promoted to EPL. If you can, though.

[u]Performance[/u]
So far in the latest save game, I've had at least 1 crash each season with medium database selected with 4 leagues active. Acceptable, and can be countered by saving often and letting autosave does its job so you don't lose your progress due to crash. 

For the game performance itself, it runs flawlessly @ 60 FPS on my limited i5 Broadwell, 8 GB RAM and 840m. The game requires processor more than graphic card, and it's good they're keeping it that way.

There's an idiotic bug though. If you use other settings than Borderless Window, you'll most likely be hit with black start up screen (FM forum contains bunch of people complaining about it). There's a workaround, but based on the game's lifecycle, this won't receive further patches or updates (12/6/2016 as this moment of writing), so you gotta bear with it if you have issues with the game.

Overall, Football Manager fans can expect the same if not better experience than when playing 2015 version.

In brief: don't spend money on this when there are better alternatives for everything it tries to do. If you want a well-constructed sports management sim, play Out Of The Park Baseball; if you want to have fun playing football, get this year's (or any year's) FIFA.

I think FM2016 tries to do too much. The "match engine" is a particular victim of this; it's little more than a visual aide for the math by which the game determines results, which often leads to impossible passes, baffling goalkeeping displays, and players who literally stand around doing nothing when the ball rolls gently past them. I don't know how much randomness is involved, but the whole thing could be run on an RNG and I wouldn't be shocked. They want it to be a good representation of the sport, but the graphics are hideous and players don't behave organically. Honestly, I would be more engaged by a static top-down view of the field that rattled off play-by-play down the side of the screen.

The core elements of the game are dense and unforgiving, with a steep learning curve for novice players. Feedback from assistant coaches - even "good" ones - is unhelpful and frequently makes things worse when their suggestions are implemented, but it's also the only way to know your tactics are working, since the game doesn't display training results for players in anything resembling a straightforward manner. Half the options for communicating with players on or off the field are useless. Half the data the game compiles on those players is also useless, and good luck parsing out the information you need in the game's sprawling, unwieldy menu system.

Having said that, some elements of the management side are okay. The transfer system more or less works, scouting is clunky but ultimately fine, and it's easy to handle off-field expectations from fans, the board, and the press. Ultimately, though, that's not enough to save the game from its flaws.

It feels like Sports Interactive is trying to have its cake and eat it too with this game. They want to make a management sim, but they also stuff it with a bunch of bloat that weighs it down and prevents them from focusing on things that could actually be helpful to players. I'm all for deep, complex games, but this one needs some major streamlining before I consider buying another iteration.

No matter what tactic I use, no matter what players I use, no matter how I manage my players' morale, it seems like everything boils down to that one coin flip before every half. It also doesn't help that when it's my own team dominating, they will just miss every occasion, while the opponent's domination will always result in a few goals.

I have tried a few careers and it always starts with me losing like 5 games in a row while completely dominating on possession and clear cut chances, and then I randomly win a game 4-0 against a top team. Nothing seems to make sense anymore. I'm touching sliders that affect the game's RNG but I have no way anymore to predict HOW they will affect the RNG.

This results in a very frustrating experience where you win some games and lose some games but you never know WHY. Everything is so random it's almost impossible to make conclusions about the choices you made. Changed a striker for another and won? It could be a billion other factors you mostly have no power over.

I understand how this can be considered like a realism improvement, because in real life there's just many parameters you have no influence over, and players actually have their little egos, but maybe, just maybe, a GAME shouldn't be all about realism and should sacrifice some of it in favor of fun and rewarding gameplay.

Football Manager. One of the rare series that would see you spend a few hundred hours at least on each edition regardless of how rubbish the game is.

This year's edition is decent. The match engine works quite well now I have to say.

Transfers are STILL too expensive, though understandable considering how the transfer market has changed since my first ever FM (2011)

The UI is a lot better than 15's. A lot more refined and with more stats you care about.

My only gripe? Leicester got relegated in 2017 in my save, therefore very unrealistic right now.

All jokes aside, if you never played an FM game before you might want to pick this one up (Or wait until 17 comes out and be inevitably unplayable until next March). If you already played FM 2015 and haven't picked this up, I reckon you should wait until there are major changes because this game really feels like FM 2015 came out of open beta. It also has to be noted that you cannot transfer your savegames from 15 to 16.

Recommended only if you want a better version of 15.

(And has anyone tried to win the league with Leicester after recent events? I know I did. I failed.)

Now that I'm out of semester I've been able to put more time and effort into this year's game. Firstly, the UI changes have been minimal but visually pleasing. I feel like there's more of a variety of tactics that can work in this game than previous versions, and "tinkering" feels more effective. The addition of prozone has been a godsend in noticing trends and meticulous statisitcs that are integral to building a squad to challenge in multiple competitions. National team coaching is still rather underwhelming and something that's likely going to be a side project rather than a focus for a save, it just doesn't have enough depth to it. Goalkeepers will always be a hot issue, but I feel that for the most part there aren't any glaring issues (except that GK match ratings are typically cruel). Youth development feels as rewarding as ever, though there is still a massive lottery when it comes to annual youth intakes.

All things considered, I'd give it a solid 8/10

This review is intended for the experienced FM player. If you are new to the series, or indeed the genre, you should buy this game. It is by far the best available in the genre. Highly recommended. 

However, if you have owned virtually every CM/FM game that has ever been released, then perhaps the following comments will constitute a review which is closer to your heart?

Somewhere along the line, these games lost their soul. The most identifiable yardstick along this path was the moment the developers introduced overall star ratings for players. There was a time, in early CM games, when signing a player was a risk. You would look at their form, stats and overall value and make a decision. Sometimes, you would buy a flop and othertimes you would make a great signing. Now all you need to do is have a good scout and you can go on the star rating they provide. That might be good for your average ADHD fifa manager type players, but people buying these games, for the most part, WANT to spend time trying to make these decisions and don't want to have their hands held through the process. In a real-world scenario, a player who has scored 20+ goals in a season immediately attracts interest from bigger clubs. In this game however, you will simply overlook such a player if their star rating is poor. In these games form has absolutely no relevance when making signings. This is NOT an accurate simulation of how decisions are made in real life.

If you are a long-standing player of these games, ask yourself this question - when was the last time you bought a player who ended up not being good enough to make it at your club? This is something real-world managers live and die by, but is an element of football management which has been woefully overlooked by the developers. Somewhere along the way the developers have made the hardest decision in football management the easiest one. Signing new players should always be a risk. Think of the countless examples in real life of signings which on paper should have been stars. If there is one thing which is clearly evident, it is that even the most experienced and talented of managers occasionally buy players who flop. This should be the most important aspect of any football management simulation. Instead, this game provides you with god-like ability to predict just how good a player will be in the future through an overall star rating. In real-life, managers would make such predictions through a combination of the player's professionalism, age, determination, injury history and availabilility of experienced players for the youngster to learn from. These factors would also fluctuate over time and be subject to change. Hence, a player like Michael Johnson at Man City comes an goes.  By forcing players to consider these things the developers could make this game SO much more rewarding and return the franchise partway to its former roots.

As for the matchday engine, it is simply a non-event. The quality is just not there to warrant ever using this view. The ardent FM fan will not even care about the 3D view as it is not the aspect of the game which they find rewarding. Rather, it is taking the plunge and signing players and working them into a functional tactical system. Incidentally, tactics is the one area of the game which the developers have virtually got spot on. You cannot sail through a season just repeat using the same system like in the good old days.

My suggestion, stop trying make a stats-driven simulation and try to return some atmosphere to the game. You can make a start by providing authentic match day sounds. I could go for hours explaining how this game could be improved, but ultimately this is intended as a review and not a 'blue-sky' suggestion session for the developers.

I will obviously keep buying these games, if only for the reason that there is no other franchise which comes close in this genre. But everytime I buy the latest version a little piece of me (and the genre) dies. It is for this reason that I have to send a message to the world that as long as this game is not fulfilling its enormous potential, I cannot in good conscience recommend it.

SI has become complacent due to the lack of competition.

I don't think the developers are upgrading the match engine. SI usually spends 3 months patching the game so the development window is probably even shorter than a year.

In other words, you are being horribly ripped off every time you pay for their 'new' product which is more like a patch developed for some months with new graphics and animations. I bet they are using the same engine they've been using for a decade because many core problems never go away in FM series. As a rule of thumbs, you should never buy products released every year.

Returning problems that plague FM every single year are still here because devs refuse to spend time to improve the game.

I took a team predicted to finish at 24th in English 6th football division. In 4 years, I won 4 leagues, promoted the team 4 times, won 8 cups, and the team's wealth was increased 50 folds. Meanwhile, my weekly wage increased from 1000 euro to 1200 euro because the board constantly tries to knock down your wage after each successful season. When I took that team to the premier league my status in the club was 'favourite'; not a legend, not even an icon.

I had two player with the exact same abilities and potential abilities. One had 1 ambition, the other had 20 ambition. The latter doesn't have an agent and the former always requests 3 times more wages and complain about not playing in a bigger club.

Interviews and commentaries are SAME word to word with FM 2006. You are forced to answer mind numbingly boring questions over and over for the same response and news.

Cross is ridiculously OP as it was in earlier versions of 2015. Match stats are wildly different from real soccer. (top players in real soccer marks 90~95% pass success rate. In FM it's 80% at best. Neuer's save rate was 91% in 2015 season. In game it's less than 60%. etc). Goalkeeper AI is horrendous. They often pick up an imaginary ball while the attacker dribbles past him.

To be honest, FM isn't a bad game. It's probably the best sports simulation game available on the market. That doesn't excuse them from cash-milking gamers with the same product every year. If you are a new player interested, sure, go ahead and buy the game. Otherwise, stick to FM you have because new versions don't offer anything new or better. New FM game is microscopically better than its previous installment.

There are a lot more problems but I will just end with this note: FM series has NOT been evolving for almost half a decade. Don't give these people your money. Support developers who actually make a better game than their previous games.

This is a review of Football Manager 2016, version 16.2.

I've (proudly? not so proudly...?) logged hundreds of hours on FM games over the years.

They have their hit or miss moments every year. The match engine is never perfect, or takes several patches to get to an enjoyable state. Year after year, features are lack luster, or it feels like the devs are holding back good ideas for future years. After buying FM year after year, I decided to hold off on new FM's until there was some real ground breaking stuff, and milk FM 2014 for every penny I could. I played the 2015 demo, and deemed it unworthy. I played the 2016 demo at first, and also found it lacking.

But after reading forums and posts by respected FM community members, I got the sense that 2016 was in a really good place as of the last patch. Many reviews i've read said that FM 16 was the most enjoyable the franchise has been in recent years... so when it finally went on sale 25% off, I decided to bite. 

And I've never enjoyed FM as much as I have in the last 30+ hours of playing. The 16.2 match engine feels great... the graphics are respectable... and the UI (after downloading my favorite FLUT skin) is beautiful. I definitely think skipping 2015 was the right move, because 2016 feels packed with features that 2014 didn't have. Like it's almost a completely different game.

If you're a veteran of FM games, and are on the fence about buying 2016. I say do it, especially if it's on sale...

If you're new to the franchise, this is probably one of the most accessible versions of the game to get in to. To get the full FM experience, I would strongly reccomend doing some research on graphics add-ons (like facepacks, logos, UI improvements, kits (jerserys), and other 3D enhancements) from fan/3rd party sites. After spending the day updating all of my graphics and images... FM 2016 is far and away my favorite iteration of the game.


tl;dr:

Buy 2016 (on sale), skip 2017 (unless it's revolutionary). Make sure to heavily customize the graphics. Profit.

Don't really do reviews, but I wanted to respond to some of the negative reviews.

Generally, I would say this is a significant improvement on FM 2015 (worth asking price? maybe, probably more so than previous incarnations.).  Improvements are mainly to UI and match/performance analysis.  

In my experience the match engine has some hiccups (way too many scores from crosses) but I have noticed a significant improvement since launch. 

To respond to negative reviews (mostly about match engine):

Will you sometimes get a match where you get 10:1 shots and lose? Yes. Will you get an unlucky season (i.e. too many key injuries) and get sacked? Sometimes. I won't say it's all perfect, but I enjoy some randomness.

I have not experienced consistent injustices in the match engine, but for those who are complaining about it: I hope you tried all sorts of different tactical adjustments and considered things like player consistency/chemistry/tactical fluidity before coming here to review the game.

The match engine must have been designed by Moynes. Every cross is an auto goal. 4 Defenders between the goal and the forward receive a cross or 0, a goalk keeper that 'Rushes out' and one that prefers to say in. A deep sitting team or one pushing forward. A cross will find the forward like a magnet. Whether the winger is crossing it from the middle of the field or by the corner flag. You can watch 5 defenders and a goalie all stupidly stare at a cross while a mediocre forward from a lower league connects with the perfect fit. 

But maybe you say I am just a bad FM. And that is possible -- except you can look at the statistics of every other team. 80% of goals are crosses. In fact thats what most matches are between two evenly matched teams, its cross and counter cross. 

The other banalities of the game are just quirks of FM -- a sliding tackle strips your player but the ball falls to another one of your player who gives it back to the sliding player -- but the crosses simply take you out of the game. Presumably some programmer watched a game once and saw a cool cross from the deep land perfectly on the tip of a strikers foot and decided that this is the only way goals can be scored.

Oh and also there is a pretty nasty memory leak. But thats usual for FM engines so if you soldiered on through to 2016 its no surprise.

The game is scripted. 

In my first test game to experiment with how things have changed since 2013 (when I last purchased a FM), it was clear that results are pre-determined based on variables which it appears are impossible to influence on match day. 

As an example, I re-played a single game five times, with three different formations (4-4-2, 4-1-3-2, 5-3-2), and slight tweaks to the two formations that seemed to work the best. 

In all five instances, the game was a 2-2 draw, with exactly the same players scoring, within a five minute range. 

In other words, no matter what I did in terms of team selection, role selection, formation selection, tactic selection and temperament selection, the game played out in precisely the same manner. 

Other games I have re-played in the range of 3-4 times, with exactly the same results as the first play through, and the same scorers (for the opposing team), but at slightly different times. 

Personally, I get the feeling that the creators of this game have lost their drive to create a simulation in favour of an easier code which can develop results based on far fewer variables which cannot be changed on match day by the player, most probably to reduce the load on the CPU, but probably to also reduce the amount of work they have to put in. 

If anyone has the same feeling I'd be welcome to discuss this issue further.

Firstly, I've gotten promoted twice in a row and qualified for champions league in years 3 - I'm going OK! I have played it for years and years, this review is not on the back of me doing badly in the game.

Basics* 
*(note - a lot about match engine, but this is a large part of what makes the game enjoyable for me)

The main issue I encountered was the quality of the match engine. Prior to the release, we heard about how the developers were improving this area of the game. However;
-Goalkeepers are making STUPID decisions, the visual standard you watch would have been disappointing in a game that's 10 years old. It hasn't a patch on the FIFA Manager game I played 10 years ago.
-Defenders are nearly as bad - they can't track a run, they give away stupid penaltys and can never cover the back post
-Tactics enforced can't really be seen in play. If you target a side in your tactics, the stat's never display this, the highlights never show it.
-Match engine overall has not improved. The lack of progress since FM15 is absolutely TERRIBLE
-Negotations are still unrealistic - small clubs will still demand 30 million for a hot prospect who has never played a game for a club.
-It still hasn't allowed for better negotiations on contracts etc. - I would have liked more career development talks etc. when taking on and dealing with young players.
-The press conferences are just irritating - again, very little progression from last year. Even most of the questions are the same.
-The 'new club' feature just isn't good. Picking a new team has been made far too irritating and long winded by the way you have to search. It's as if the developers got bored at this part and just gave up before they were finished. I was really excited about this feature, but it has a number of HUGE flaws too such as you're able to get players who haven't got work permits, then if they can't be renewed at the end of the season - they're gone (I lost half of my team after the first season on free transfers because of it).

Overall, I would advise getting FM15 for a fraction of the price and getting an update for the new players etc. This is one of the worst updates I've played and it's really not worth the effort that has been put in since the release of FM15. I really don't think they're keeping with the times, there are lots of new features that they could of added but haven't.

- The aforementioned point makes the matches feel extremely predictable as you either absolutely smash opposition, go ninety minutes without a single chance or get the dreaded late conceded goal and all is visible/predictable due to the way your/opposing players move about on the pitch during the whole match/last minutes.

- Different tactical approach isn't as visible on-screen as one might imagine, which gives little incentive to create/tweak own tactics.

- Corner instructions are ignored (short corner instruction results in floating crosses being hit).

- Generally lack of new features with the exception of the terrible manager creator screen.

It is difficult to recommend a game when it really is an update of an existing formula rather than a new game. I think it is time SI started treating each new iteration as DLC rather than a new title, I do recommend this version, but hesitantly. 

That out of the way, is it a good update? Yes. (and no?)

Bad thing first: The new create your own club function is silly and needs TONS of work, you'd think that if they introduce this sort of functionality they'd make sure it was user friendly even as part of DLC. It isn't, all it is is a means to do an editor botch job on an existing club, take their place in the league, change the name, place and colours to your heart's content and finally get really frustrated trying to work out which players you want to add to the club whilst not having anything other than a player-name filter. So that striker you remember plays for Scunthorpe but you don't know his name? Don't imagine you can find him, you can't. 

Good things: The U/I has been cleaned up successfully, not just interface wise but also interaction wise, you don't have to do silly repetitive interviews each game any more for example. The game looks clean and fresh, even the 3D engine is now sort of worth using. Another good thing is that the opposing managers/teams now respond to your tactical foibles better, when I added a striker after going 1-0 down the opposing manager didn't wait and switched to a counter-attacking formation straight away, when we equalised anyway he dropped further back but put on a lighting fast striker instead of his targetman. I have never experienced that before in FM20** it used to be more like playing against a scripted bot. 

Best thing: The match-engine has had significant work to make it more realistic. I am only a season in so far, but I am very impressed with not just the impact my decisions have on the flow of the game, but also the fact that players seem more creative in their interpretation of my instructions, adapting to the flow of the game if they are more experienced, flapping around the field aimlessly after a mistake if they are youngsters and compounding the problems. Compared to 2015 the tactical side of the game has improved beyond cosmetics, which is what the game should be all about.

I would like to preface this by saying a few things: First, I've been playing FM games for about 10 years now, so while I don't have as much experience as others, I'd still say I'm quite familiar with the game.

Secondly, upon reading many of the reviews here (mostly the negative ones), I have to say - a game being "too hard" isn't a valid reason to give a negative review; it just means you either don't understand the game, or you're just plain bad at it.

Alright, onto the review. As I've said, I've played this franchise for quite a while now, with thousands of hours pumped into it, and I must say that this is probably the most balanced of them all. I say that for a couple of reasons. First, I don't run away with games against teams I have no business beating. It sounds like a lot of people on here will take a team like Aston Villa and expect to be world beaters, lose to Man Utd, and say "the game's cheating, I lost." Look at the real life table and you'll see something shocking! Villa are dead last. You're not meant to win every game all the time. I'm sorry, but you're not - if you did, the game would be broken. 

I find it funny that people come into sim games and expected it to be realistic, but only if you're winning, like you're the best manager in the world. If a real life, qualified, and experienced manager can't get wins, or stay afloat in the top flight, what kind of gall do you have to think you're better than somebody who does it for a living? It's a bit arrogant.

Yes, I understand it's a video game, and that you, as the player, have a hero complex. You've played Mario, you're a fat Italian plumber who's doing acrobatics and crap, killing monsters. Then you play FM and bring that mentality to a sim game, and get pissy when you're garbage. Well, Mario isn't a realistic game is it? We all know Italians can't do anything, let alone save a princess over and over again. ;)

Jokes aside, the positives of this game vastly outweigh the negatives. Another positive to the match engine is the realism in the highlights and game play. In the past I've noticed that in the final 10 minutes or so, teams would dominate you. This was incredibly present in FM15. It didn't seem to matter who the teams were - Spain vs. Malta, didn't matter, Malta would destroy the final ten with nearly 100% possession. Sure, it could be written off as tactics, and player fatigue, and all that, but it was too consistent to be a fluke. This version has none of that. Evenly matched teams seems to have equal spells of possession through the game, which is good. 

There are still some issues with possession mind you. I have found that in the majority of my matches, even against superior teams, I'm dominating the possession and shot game. In fact, it can be a bit ridiculous at times with me having upwards of 75% control over the game. I suppose it's a good problem to have.

Let's take a look at scorelines. Again, in past installments, scores could reach outrageous numbers on a consistent basis. I can't tell you how many times I was apart of 5-3 games. Sure, it happens. But not 15-20 times a season. FM 16 provides more realistic scores, despite the odd possession bias. Most of my games are 1-0, 2-1, etc... I had one 4-0 game. There really isn't much more to say on this other than it seems like it's more realistic.

Defending - oh boy, this has been a personal problem of mine for years in this game. I just don't have the tactical know-how to keep the ball out of my own net, and I like many, ticked it up to a poor ME. This year's version I'm quite pleased with. Either I figured out the defending myself, or the game changed to allow more realistic scorelines. I don't mind losing - it's part of football. But I HATE losing 5-0. It was a turn off for me, and often times I would just quit and not play for a few days because of that. Like I said, save for one game where we scored 4, I haven't seen obnoxious scorelines for seemingly no reason. It's good, I like it.

"But, we've dominated the game, have 30 shots, and lost 1-0. The game is broken." - Many negative reviews. I suppose these people have never heard of defending/counter attacking. Absolutely that can happen. Look at Chelsea's Champions League win a few years back. They sat in their own end the entire game, and scraped out a win. It's not pretty, but when you're up against a stronger team, it's what you have to do. I feel the AI in this game is better than it has been in years past. Opposition knows when they're up against a stronger team, and they pretty much line up 10 guys at the edge of the box, forcing you to have control and possession, taking bad shots, and frustrating your strikers. All the while, they're sucking your defenders in. Fullbacks get too deep, to try for the wide ball, and central defenders slowly creep forward losing the only striker up front. Next thing ya know, they have a 1-on-1, and you're down 1. You get pissed off and say it's broken. I say, change your tactic. Draw the defense out, so press so much. Etc...

Football is a complex game, and FM 16 is just as complex. If you don't want realistic football, if you want to go and rout your opponents at every turn, play FIFA. Managing a team in a realistic setting is frustrating, but it also has it's rewards. And in this version, I feel that SI has finally nailed down a realistic, fun, and interesting experience. 

There are other aspects I haven't touched upon, like the transfers, UI, and press conferences. But other than the new design, it's all pretty much the same old. The new skin looks alright, takes a bit getting used to, but ya know, you can just get a mod. :)

I honestly cannot understand all the negative reviews for this game.

I've been a longtime follower of the series since the early "Championship Manager" games. I'm the first to admit that some of the latest games have been subpar, or had too many issues.

However, Football Manager 2016 felt stable since the early access Beta, which was very surprising given how usually it took SI at least a month or two before a patch made the game actually playable. I also feel that this Match Engine, contrary to what other people are saying here, feels much more realistic than the previous one. I only had two or three very unusual results, but people forget that these happen in football in real life.

I can't comment on the 3D graphics (which admittedly, still have a long way before they could be considered "acceptable" for this era), as I've always played the series in 2D mode for a more tactical approach. But graphics are most certainly the least of the matters considering a managerial game. 

The new game mode (Fantasy Draft) is awesome, and playing it with friends is a blast too, especially if you're a fan of playing fantasy football. My only complaint, relative to all Network modes, is that the game still feels a bit "wonky" while playing online, with people reporting latency issues when issuing commands, but this could be optimized with future patches.

Overall, I would suggest to buy this year's Football Manager, especially if you've been holding off last year, as this has one of the most realistic Match Engines of the series. The interface has been polished as well, with particular care to the Tactics section, which is now more "graphic", and the new set pieces tab is a very nice touch. Speaking of Touch, the game mode offers three new skins for the interface that are optimized for touchscreen displays, though it's not the most intuitive option to activate, and they could have done a little more on that part.

[b]TL;DR: This year's version is the one you should buy. Do not listen to the negative reviews: the game has been stable and realistic since the Beta.[/b]

I think this is the first Football Manager in a few years to offer some actual innovations rather than just 'tinkering' with the system and interface.  It's about time that happened as well as some aspects in the game were getting really quite dated, especially the match engine.

On the subject of the match engine: It really looks like they have tackled this in 2016, especially regarding the goalkeeper and defence, who now actually interact as players on the pitch instead of just going through the motions for the engine.

Tactics ACTUALLY seem to work for once, so asking for direct football will actually get you direct football with forceful wingers and killer balls attempted.  They had started to try and fix this in 2015, but still seemed like they were going through the motions to mask a pretty average match engine. 

I am really enjoying the new detailed staff page as well, you can now see exactly who is doing what at the club, and where your club ranks in the league at staff skills.  This was always an underdeveloped part of the game for me, as a club's backroom staff is just as important as the players on the pitch.

I hear the prozone is good as well, but not something I have looked at in detail as of yet.

There are, however, still some issues:

The blighted over developed press conferences are still in the game.  MY GOD these are boring, and I don't think SI actually realise how dull they have made this, which is ironic as a lot of development time seem to have gone into making it 'intuitive'.  Let's make this clear though - intuitive means nothing if it isn't entertaining.  My solution is simple...drop all the press nonsense, that just kills playing time, and allow people to have a preset button which gives you avatar a way of dealing with the press - range it from 'conspiracy theorist' right through to 'upbeat and passive'.  You can then change you demeanor as and when you see fit - so if you are in a slump you can do the 'world is against us' mentality if you wish to, without having to spend 5 mins reading through very dull rhetorical journo questions! The whole 'get your assistant manager to do it' just doesn't wash for me either, as press management is an important part of creating a team mentality.

The interface still looks like it was developed by a sociopath, however I get SI not caring too much as Steklo will no doubt just create a great new indie Skin over the next couple of months anyway.
I am already enjoying the game, even if it is the beta. This already seems like a very developed game, and I am so excited to see what happens when the full game is released.

Buy this game if you like being locked in a room all day, vitamin D deficiencies, and just simply don't want to deal with the confinements of real life anymore. Because trust me, once you play this game, there is no going back. The only people interaction you will have in the real world is with the Pizza delivery person.

Pros: 
+ New Prozone match analysis is extremely useful especially for those who create their own tactics, and speaking of tactics; the tactics manager is refined and is easier to use than ever. With a completely redesigned set piece creator that makes the difference between building a winning tactic and a losing one much more distinct. It's easier to see where your tactics are going wrong / right, and because of this, if it's going wrong you're going to be able to figure it out much more easier than last year's iteration. 
+ Draft Mode is a winner, Who doesn't love fantasy football? Now you can have it inside your favourite football management sim.
+ Injuries aren't as horrifically prominent as they were during the early builds of last year's game. 
+ Create-A-Club mode allows you to create your own team and lead your creation to glory. (Replaces a team in the league you choose)
+ Realistic data for almost every player in the WORLD playing across tens of thousands of different leagues. That's just phenomenal!
+ Refined matchday Engine with better 3d graphics.
+ Still easily the best football management simulation in the world, and most likely it forever will be with the sheer amount of work put into this database. This game is a literal universe inside your PC, load it up and you'll be sucked into another dimension where suddenly YOU were actually good at football in the past, and have retired to lead Wigan Athletic to champions league glory. 

Meh:
= Press interaction is slightly more varied this year, no more pressing random buttons and hoping you didn't say something to piss your star player off. The new conferences will keep you intrigued for at least the first 24 hours of gameplay. (Then it's back to your ol' Assistant Manager because you have nothing to say A la Jose Mourinho)
= Customizing your own manager is neat, but it lacks options. There are only a few different choices for hair styles, colors, and outfits. It doesn't prove to be the immersive feature it is advertised as, because I couldn't copy my likeness. 
= The beta is not without it's fair share of bugs, from the silly, to the game crashing; and i'm sure the first versions of the full game are likely to have some too, but it's to be expected with the sheer size of this game. It will just get better over time though, as the devs are highly active and the final version of FM15 was almost bug free from my experience.  

Cons:

Wow, what a difference!  FM16 is much better than the poor shadow of a game that FM15 was.  

Just some quick comments:

1.  The goalie AI is miles better.  The reactions are more realistic, and diving saves are made when they are meant to.  A lot less opposition goals scored with keeper just standing there.  I feel like my team has a locked door again!!

2.  The defence AI is also much improved.  Where last year they would let players through easily, there is a real feeling that the defenders respond to tactics you set and that makes such a positive difference.  

3.  I love the new animations for scoring, celebrating, remonstrating, falling and tackling.  I really like the little flicks of the ball that have been introduced as well.  Also some nice improvements in the build of players' faces on the pitch.  My computer was rated 3* for graphics, but there has been no problem with the best quality setting being used.

4.  The new tactics screen is super.  It makes it a lot more clear to use the 'pie' graphic to show whether the players are suited to a position and now a role.  Much much better.

5.  The new manager builder is a great idea.  I kind of managed to match my face but I have heavy stubble and glasses - any chance that SI could introduce facial hair and glasses settings for this?  Wouldn't mind so much if it was just for the match engine, but my attempt at my face comes up whenever I am quoted on screen and whatever.  However, that is the only thing I don't like about the manager builder.

6.  Injury frequency is much fairer than in FM15.  I no longer have an injury list the size of Glasgow.  I've gone from a consistent injury list of 8 first team players out to just 1 or 2 - much more realistic.  This makes such a difference SI - please don't change it when you release the final version.  

7.  Injury type and associated time out of the team is much better balanced than in FM15.  The option to play through injury is good too.  SI have listened to us here, which is excellent.  I was kind of dreading playing this game after forking out for the beta, simply because the injury system crippled FM15 in my eyes, and I was afraid that this would be more of the same.  I am very happy that I have been proved wrong.

8.  The prozone tactical system is great.  Now we can access substitutions in a much slicker fashion, and it doesn't take an age to go through.  This helps the game continue quickly.  

9.  There is a definite distinction between match fitness and match sharpness, and both affect the performance of the players in their own way.  A lot of thought has gone into this, and it works extremely well, even in beta. 

Can you tell I'm a little impressed??

10.  I haven't tried the team builder yet but looking it over, it seems a great option.  I'll comment more fully when I have the chance.

SI, thank you for giving us a much better offering (so far) this season.  I will be playing this version of FM a lot more than I played the last one.

[h1] Football Manager 2016 Beta First Impressions [/h1]

[b]Hey guys, I'm about to write my first impressions about the game, but keep in mind that this is beta / pre-order version. Also, this review is intended for Football Manager players that already know how to play this game.[/b]

Pros: 


[list]
    [*] Most advanced animations yet in any Football Manager edition. What I mean by that is the fact that FINALLY you can see the difference in Flair / Quality between 2 players. New dribblings, crosses, decisions and finishing in front of goal. It was FM13 since I've been asking for more realistic dribblings / decisions / crosses in the final third but the game never got quite there, until now. Let me give you a short example: I am playing as AC Milan and Jeremy Menez was attacking the right flank as a Winger-Attack. In any of the previous versions, he would have done 3 possible things: attack the byline and cross, cutting into the penalty area or pass the ball back to the overlappting full back. Now, I noticed something absolutly beautiful: He did neither of those. His decision was to dribble 2 players like they were nothing by cutting inside the penalty area and then he launched a lobbed-cross to Luiz Adriano who was rushing forward from a deeper position. Now, besides his way of dribbling (which i've never seen before in FM), we can easily notice another MAGNIFICENT improvement: lobbed crosses. This kind of crosses are a must in a game like FM and I am finally happy it was introduced. So yes, new animations / decisions / dribblings / crossings. You can finally see the difference between 15 Flair and 18 Flair so to speak.
    [*] Game is in a much better state beta wise than it was last year (loading times, match engine and leagues)
    [*] Fast loading / saving times. Last year's beta was awful regarding saving times. It was something that eventually got fixed, but FM16 doesn't have this problem at all. In fact, to me it seems than the game loads/saves faster than FM15.
    [*] 3D Match Engine is another thing that pleasantly surprised me (played 3 games). By this I mean it feels smoother, no visible glitches and artefacts. Last year we had all sorts of problems with 3d engine performance until it got fixed (the game ran choppy and stuttering a lot on anything above "medium" quality no matter how powerful your machine was). In this regard, FM 2016 shines right from the start. I am able to play the game on highest graphical settings.
    [*] One of the biggest improvements in my opinion is ProZone analysis tool. This tool is so so much better than what we had before. If you are the kind of manager that likes to keep tabs on every aspect of the tactic you are creating, than I swear, ProZone is exactly what you've been waiting for. 
    [*] New tactical framework is excelent  in my opinion, definetly much better than last year's, especially if you are a newcomer to the game. For new players it is much easier to make them understand what each setting does and for the experienced players, well, it makes their "job" easier.
    [*] Another pro of FM 16 is the actual Player Profile Screen which wasn't completly revamped but the slight adjustments SI made are welcome. You can get almost every necessary info about a player just by clicking Profile Tab.
    [*] Contract negociations screen has been completly revamped and its new look is very neat. It wasnt bad in any of the previous versios, but these new adjustments are always welcome.
[/list] 

Cons:

[list]
    [*] The only con that I feel I must put out is how the Formation Tactic screen looks like. By this, I mean the players on the pitch in the tactics screen. I feel that player's "thumbnail" takes way way too much space than it needs to. This gives me some sort of claustrophobic feeling. This is something that bothers me, but it might not bother anybody else.
[/list]

Now, I didn't write about all the new features that SI has introduced because that's not relevant for this review. I felt like I only need to adress things that need to be adressed considering the game is still in BETA state. This said, I conclude this review by stating that FM16 BETA seems far better than FM15 BETA and I will enjoy every minute of it. I will write a full review after the game comes out in the final version (13 November). By then I will know more. Consider this review, as a review at a glance if you will. Enjoy the best football manager simulator out there.

I also recorded some videos of it, which you can see on my profile/YT channel.
